headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Solar Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being webcast live on the investor section of First Solar's website at www.firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] Today's program is
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Solar Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being webcast live on the investor section of First Solar's website at www.firstsolar.com. [Operator Instructions] Today's program is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Larry Polizzotto, Vice President of Investor Relations for First Solar. Mr. Polizzotto, you may begin.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for First Solar's Second Quarter 2011 Conference Call. Today after the market closed, the company issued a press release announcing our second quarter financial results and our guidance update for 201
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for First Solar's Second Quarter 2011 Conference Call. Today after the market closed, the company issued a press release announcing our second quarter financial results and our guidance update for 2011. If you did not receive a copy of the press release, you can obtain one from the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. In addition, we have posted the presentation for this call, as well as well as quarterly statistics and historical data on financial and operating performance on our IR website. We'll be discussing the presentation during the call and webcast. An audio replay of the conference call will also be available approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of the call. The audio replay will remain available until Tuesday, August 9, 2011, at 7:30 p.m. Eastern daylight time and can be accessed by dialing (888) 203-1112 if you're calling from within the United States, or (719) 457-0820 if you're calling from outside the United States, and entering the replay pass code 66473845. A replay of the webcast will be available on the Investors section at firstsolar.com approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of the call, and will remain available for 90 calendar days. If you're a subscriber of FactSet or Thomson One, you can obtain a written transcript. 
With me today are Rob Gillette, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Widmar, Chief Financial Officer. Rob will present an overview of the company's second quarter results and give you an update of the market and business. Mark will review our second quarter financial results and update guidance for 2011. We will then open up the call for questions. During the Q&A period, as a courtesy of those individuals seeking to ask questions, we ask that participants limit themself to one question. First Solar has allocated approximately one hour for today's call. I want to remind everyone that all financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, except free cash flow, which is a non-GAAP financial measure, which is reconciled to the operating cash flow in the back of our presentation. 
Now I'd like to make a brief statement regarding our forward-looking remarks that you may hear on today's call. During the course of this call, the company will make projections and other comments that are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Securities laws. The forward-looking statements in this call are based on current information and expectations and are subject to uncertainties and changes in circumstances and do not constitute guarantees of future performance. Those statements involve a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements, including the risks as described in the company's most recent annual report on Form 10-K and other filings within the Securities and Exchange Commission. First Solar assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking information contained in this call or with respect to announcements described herein. 
During the third quarter, First Solar will be attending the following conferences and events: First, Pacific Crest Technology Conference in Vail Colorado on August 8; Bank of America Merrill Lynch Clean Tech Conference in New York City, September 13; DnB NOR Renewable Energy Conference in Oslo on September 13; ThinkEquity's Growth Conference in New York City on September 14; Ardour's Capital Energy Tech Conference in New York city on September 15; Credit Suisse Future of Energy Conference in New York City, September 27. And now it's my pleasure to introduce Rob Gillette, Chief Executive Officer of First Solar. Rob?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. Welcome to our Q2 earnings call. As all of you know, it was a challenging quarter for the solar PV industry, including First Solar, but on our execution service well in and we're positioned for a significant and better second half.Startin
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. Welcome to our Q2 earnings call. As all of you know, it was a challenging quarter for the solar PV industry, including First Solar, but on our execution service well in and we're positioned for a significant and better second half.
Starting with Slide 6. Q2 net sales of $533 million, that's about 6% lower than last quarter, primarily due to lower average selling prices. Solar PV power uncertainties in Italy, Germany and France adversely impacted demand in the second quarter. Net sales are also impacted as the reallocated modules for systems business which we did not recognize as revenue within the quarter.
Second quarter net income was $61 million or 11.5% of net sales, resulting in diluted EPS of $0.70. Return on net assets was 13.1% on a 4-quarter rolling basis representing an EVA of about 1.1%. Our cash and marketable securities balance of $515 million declined $198 million sequentially as we invested CapEx for new factories and continued construction of several systems projects.
In addition, shipments were weighted to the end of the quarter as customers delayed orders until the European policy changes were better understood.
Despite the challenging European market in the first half of the year, our 2011 outlook remains solid due to our differentiated and resilient business model. We expect significantly better performance in the remainder of 2011 as we build project from our systems pipeline, developed promising new markets and execute our cost and efficiency roadmaps. As a result, our updated 2011 EPS guidance is $9 to $9.50 for fully diluted share which includes 450 megawatts of system sales and some updated assumptions which Mark will discuss later.
Significant drivers in the change of the 2% increase in the effective tax rate were about $0.20 per share reduction, driven by the increased of profits in the U.S.
Moving on now to operations. Q2 production was 483 megawatts, up 40% versus the prior year and up 19% quarter-over-quarter. It's sequential increase is driven by the production ramp of the KLM 6 factory and early start up of Frankfurt/Oder 2. Module revenue shipments were up 6% quarter-over-quarter which partially offset the decline in average selling prices. A portion of the incremental production also went into systems project construction for which revenue was not has not yet been recognized. Our conversion efficiency was 11.7%, which is up 0.5 percentage points year-over-year and flat quarter-over-quarter. Module manufacturing and cost per watt was $0.75, which is flat quarter-over-quarter. The benefit of our modules from low-cost manufacturing sites was offset by FX, lower line throughput, higher spending and factory ramp costs. Coal costs which included the ramp penalty and stock-based compensation, were $0.73 per watt. And we're very pleased to announce that our Malaysian plant have achieved a new core cost milestone of $0.69 per watt.
Annual capacity per line decreased by 2 megawatts quarter-over-quarter to 62.1-megawatt per line. Line throughput and cost per watt were both impacted this quarter as we decided to take advantage of softer industry demand with scheduled downtime and begin to implement conversion efficiency improvements which we expect will have a meaningful impact by the end of the year.
We also reached a milestone with our standard utility-scale balance of systems by achieving a cost level of $0.99 per watt. BoS is down 29% from the second quarter of 2009. We are now also close to our 2014 target for standard BoS of $0.91 to $0.98 per watt and can improve further as our plan Module efficiencies increase from 13.5% to 14.5% by the end of 2014. This major accomplishment is the result of our experienced investment in engineering and R&D and cycles of learning from almost 400 megawatts of DC of projects built to date.
To summarize our manufacturing capacity addition, Malaysia 5 and 6 are at full production; order 2 begin ramping a month early and is expected to be at full production by the end of the third quarter. Construction of our Mesa, Arizona and Vietnam sites are progressing on schedule for shipments in the third quarter of 2012.
Moving now to Page 7. Despite the recent market turbulence, our growth strategy remains unchanged. We are focused on our mission of making solar affordable and sustainable to gain access to the multi-terawatt peak electricity generation market. We are currently in the transition phase as fits and other government policies are progressing towards parity and market diversification continues. First Solar has made significant progress reducing a levelized cost of electricity, diversifying geographically, and we expect price declines to continue to drive demand elasticity.
On the next page, you can see we've made significant progress in lowering our total systems caused by 30% in 3 years. We can reduce debt by another 19%, we believe that we can provide turnkey utility-scale systems that generate power at an LCOE of $0.10 to $0.12 per kilowatt hour and higher ratings those like the U.S. Southwest, India, China, Australia, the Middle East, Spain and Italy. This is what will drive our participation in the peak electricity generation market.
Now turning to Page 9. Our Module manufacturing cost a steadily declined since 2008 and improvements to our year-end 2014 target are primarily driven by conversion efficiency growth, 13.5% to 14.5% efficiency and annual line throughput improvements to 80-megawatt per line. We are committed to our long-term Module conversion efficiency roadmap and we invest heavily in technology to achieve this end. Our investments in technology are not focused on hero cells. We emphasize track improvements with the low-cost pathways to implementation and production. However, it is nice to see that when we integrate several of these improvements, we are able to deliver a device that does exceed that has exceeded prior world record. We recently received confirmation from an Roe that first solar cells achieved a record 17.3% efficiency for CDT udenafil which breaks the previous record of 16.7% which was set in 2001.
Unlike other sell records, the cell was constructed using only full-scale manufacturing processes and commercial materials. Therefore, we believe they can be reproduced economically. This is an important milestone because it validates our technology capabilities and significantly through CDT thin film efficiencies and it provides confidence and improvements to the flat over the next 2 years. Our achievement is a direct result of our industry-leading annual investment in research and development, and the efforts of the committed team that you see here. We are considering approaches to accelerate Module efficiency quicker than our prime roadmap of the 13.5% to 14.5% by the end of 2014 to support rooftop and other high-efficiency applications.
The next page shows how we have been steadily diversifying geographically and investing in market development. Our North American business has grown from 17% to 25% of megawatt shift and is expected to be our number 1 market in 2012. In India, supportive policies and new local partners are driving strong growth and we expect India to account for more than 10% of our megawatts this year. Our North American pipeline and new markets like India are helping to offset European market uncertainties and both are expected to be multi-gigawatt sustainable markets.
In the second quarter, North America and India combined represented almost 50% of our revenues.
Moving to Page 11. The market development we're focused on executing on North American systems pipeline, managing through European market uncertainty and developing new markets. In North America, we made progress executing on the 450-megawatt DC of plant 2011 systems built and have flexibility to build up to 500 megawatts. Agua Caliente now has a significant portion of the BoS completed and we have begun installing modules. The sale of Agua Caliente to NRG and the closing of the debt financing including the BOE loan guarantee are expected soon. All major steps have been completed and we are in the funding stage. We will begin to recognize the revenue for the construction of this 290-megawatt AC system in Q3. When completed, it will be more than 3x larger than any PV power plant currently operating.
We are focused on adding to our systems pipeline on a global basis through new RPs, EPC agreements and acquisitions. For example, we recently added 150-megawatt AC, EPC agreement with Sanford Generation for the Copper Mountain 2 in Boulder Citi, Nevada. This growth to our systems pipelines about 2.6 gigawatts. Sunlight, Topaz and AVSR1 achieved $4.5 billion of DOE loans, conditional commitments in Q2. Topaz received its conditional use permit and is in the legal appeal period. AVSR is expected to begin construction in the third quarter. In Europe, we are managing through market uncertainty due to feed-in tariff and policy changes. The delayed implementation of a new decree in Italy, the slow start to Germany after January FiT reductions and lack of clarity with respect to France's tender process contributed to excess channel inventories for the industry.
During the second quarter, we work with customers to enable discrete project realization and we increased rebates to enable distributors to sell-through. In France, First Solar and our partners are realizing 250 megawatts of projects in 2011. Now we have a clearer picture in Italy, Germany, France and the U.K., but the new policies have created a more challenging operating environment.
We are making progress in developing new markets. Our 2011 plant shipments in India have now grown to more than 200 megawatts, which is up from 100 megawatts in Q1 and 10-megawatt sold in 2010. We recently signed 4 new Module customers in India and have contracted more than 250 megawatts year-to-date for deliveries in 2011 and into 2012. We are seeing an increasing number of tenders as well in the Middle East for 2012 and beyond.
On Page 12, this is the latest analyst consensus forecast of global PV market demand. On average, the FiT analyst included in the survey estimates that the 2011 market will grow to 19.8 gigawatts, up 19% year-over-year, primarily driven by North America, Italy, India and China. The analyst estimates estimate a compound growth rate of 12% from 2010  to 2013 as the markets diversified in North America, India, China, Japan, the Middle East and the rest of the world beyond Europe. Government policies, lower pricing, stellar resource and economics are driving market diversification and demand elasticity. These markets have transitioned into stable markets as we anticipated in our growth strategy.
In general, we believe demand in the major markets will improve in the second half of 2011 after a difficult first half. We see a significant growth opportunities long-term as new markets are emerging and we advance towards good parity. The German market is recovering from a slow start and appears to be ramping towards around 4 to 5 gigawatt in 2011. The recent EEG decision provides good long-term visibility and we our well-positioned at the german manufacturer.
In Italy, the market is adjusting to the new CE4 published in May is recovering from a power interruption in the first half. Demand is improving and is expected to be 2 to 3 gigawatts in 2011. Stable and reliable regular utility frameworks will be the key elements for long-term sustainable development of the Italian market. First Solar technology and Europe manufacturing expansion will help to position us for success in the Italian market.
France's policy does not provide sufficient long-term visibility at the moment while we continue to be optimistic about the longer-term opportunity. In the short-term, due to building grandfather projects, the French market should range from 500 to 800 megawatts. Our 2 line facility at Blanquefort remains on indefinite hold.
The North American market should double to more than 2 gigawatts this year. In California, over 1 gigawatt of RFOs were issued for the 2011 cycle to comply with the 33% RPS requirement. Overtime, the requirement for government subsidies may decline as ROEs or early adopters do the same.
In China, the government is in the process of developing a longer-term plan for the market. With the potential to increase their 2020 goal from 20 to 50 gigawatts. China recently announced the new national FiT with the potential to provide sustainable economics by 1.15 RMB per kilowatthour. We continued to see strong momentum in India, the market is expected to grow to about 500 megawatts in 2011.
Now Australia, we were unfortunately, not selected for the first phase of the Solar Flagship's program but remained well-positioned for the second phase. Solar growth will be strongly supported in the future by the recently announced National Carbon legislation, which has committed to invest $10 billion in non-wind large scale renewables and to the implementation of state solar programs targeting utility-scale projects.
In Southeast Asia, we see encouraging signs of early-stage development in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines. Finally, we see great potential in the Middle East. There are challenges facing oil supporting countries with the rapid growth in domestic energy needs, tenders for utility-scale projects are underway and we expect to achieve more robust renewable policies that could drive several hundred megawatt markets in just a few years.
On the next page, you can see how we've grown our systems pipeline over time. We signed a 150-megawatt AC EPC agreement with Sanford Generation for the expansion of Copper Mountain in Boulder Citi, Nevada. This site was originally developed by First Solar and sold to Sempra, which is ion PPA with PG&E for the electricity generated at Copper Mountain 2. Our goal is to continue to replace current year construction with new PPA or EPC agreements to continue to grow our pipeline.
The orange line shows our increasing project construction from 12 megawatts in 2008, to the plan 450 megawatts in 2011, and we expect to build 1 gigawatt in 2012. The slide also illustrates the expansion and diversification of our Utility Systems customer base, including IPPs, utilities, and financial investors. In the back of this presentation, Slide 23 shows the details of the North American contracted project we are executing and have under development.
On Page 14, you can see some of the project activity in the second quarter. We now have completed a significant portion of the Mott’s instruction on Agua Caliente and have begun Module installation. and The Santa Teresa projects are nearly completed, and Paloma and PNM projects are ahead of schedule.
To summarize, we continued to execute in the quarter despite a challenging European market and remain focused on achieving our mission. Our visibility is improving for the second half of the year, an increasing portion of our revenues and profits are under our control as we construct our systems pipeline and continue to diversify geographically. Our LCOE is approaching grid parity which should drive elasticity and demand and a growth of sustainable markets. We are investing for growth in the United States, India, the Middle East, Australia and China. We are executing a systems pipeline and we are adding to it. We continue to expand our factories and drive our product roadmaps. We achieved a major BoS and Module efficiency and also as a result of our investment in R&D in our continuous improvement processes and we have the financial strength to continue investing in the long-term future of our business.
Finally, our 2011 guidance is solid due to our differentiated and resilient business model. Now I'd like to turn it over to Mark who will discuss our second quarter financial performance and updated guidance for 2011. Mark?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob, and good afternoon, everyone. Looking at Slide 17, our net sales for the second quarter were $533 million, down 6% quarter-over-quarter. The decrease was primarily driven by lower ASPs which were down 13% quarter-over-quarter as the reduce
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob, and good afternoon, everyone. Looking at Slide 17, our net sales for the second quarter were $533 million, down 6% quarter-over-quarter. The decrease was primarily driven by lower ASPs which were down 13% quarter-over-quarter as the reduce prices to sell-throughs. As Rob said earlier, the quarter started slowly due to the European policy uncertainties which adversely impacted demand for the quarter. These impacts were partially offset by the positive effects of increased systems revenue recognition driven by Santa Teresa, Paloma and PMA. Our EPC revenue mix increased from 8% of total net sales in the first quarter through 11% of net sales in the second quarter. We also increased the Module allocation for the systems business during the quarter and contracted delivery schedules which resulted in revenue recognition of the second half of the year.
The early increase from Q2 to Q1, however, the stronger euro had a minor negative impact on net sales as were significant hedged in line with our long-term strategy. Gross margin was 36.6%, down 9.2 percentage points from the prior quarter. The decline was the result of the ASPs decreases, a mix shift both geographically and to more system sales and an unfavorable OpEx impact. Module gross margin was 40.2%, down 9.5 percentage points from the prior quarter. Operating expenses were flat quarter-over-quarter. Slightly higher R&D expenses associated with efficiency improvements were offset by lower production start up costs as Frankfurt/Oder and Malaysia ramped. SG&A was flat quarter-over-quarter. We saw managing an expense growth to help partially offset lower gross margin.
Operating income was $65 million compared to $129 million in the first quarter. The decline was due to the decrease in total net sales and gross margins. Operating margin for the quarter was 12.1% compared to 22.8% in the prior quarter. As we progress through the year, our operating margin is levered to the timing of the systems revenue recognition. Second quarter net income was $61 million or $0.70 per fully diluted share. The effective tax rate grows 2.2 percentage points to 15% due to the mixed shift of profits to higher tax jurisdictions which lowered EPS by $0.02 in the quarter.
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow summary. Cash and marketable securities were down quarter-over-quarter with $515 million. Accounts receivable trade balance rose quarter-over-quarter due to the nominal shipments as policy changes in Europe pushed our customers orders to the back half of the quarter. Accounts receivable non-build increased because of growth in North America business and the timing of project billing cycle providing customer contracts. Inventories increased as we increase production from a KLM 6 and FFO2 and due to more Module balance systems materials in transit EPC installations in the third quarter. Project assets rose as we continue to develop North America project sites. We continue to invest to increase our factory capacity and we have the long-term bits to help finance Malaysia and German expansions.
Operating cash flow was negative $203 million and free cash flow was negative $408 million. We spent $221 million of capital expenditures and depreciation was $54 million. Cash flow was impacted by accounts receivable linearity, growth in project assets and inventory and deferred revenue growth on more construction in progress in our systems business. Also, we invested about $52 million more on capital expenditures compared to the first quarter of 2011.
As expected, we consumed cash in the first half of the year and planned to generate cash in the second half of 2011 as we complete the sales projects in our systems business. Our balance sheet remains strong with a debt to equity ratio of 10%. This brings to our updated guidance for 2011. We have made several key assumptions underlying our guidance. Our stock exchange rate assumption of $1.40 per euro. For the third quarter, about 69% of our net sales and all of our expected net income are hedged in an average rate of $1.34 per euro. For the balance of the year, about 72% of our net sales and all of our expected net income are hedged in an average rate of $1.35 per euro. As of today, a 1 cent change in the euro dollar stock exchange rate would impact our revenue guidance for the year by about $1 million and will not change our net income guidance since we are fully hedged for 2011. Our Module pricing reflects European FiT changes in 2011 it is embedded to enable sell-through economics and is based on our estimate of the current competitive market.
We plan to build approximately 450-megawatt DC of systems projects in North America. We have the flexibility to increase this amount to 500-megawatt should the demand in other markets fell short of our current expectations. However, that flexibility has declined and will continue to decline as we progressed through the year.
We plan to minimize our expense growth in the second half of 2011. Malaysia Plants 5 and 6 are fully ramped and we are ramping that flow-through in Q3. Our capital expenditures is primarily for capacity expansion in Vietnam and the U.S..
Page 20 shows that based on these assumptions, we expect net sales to be in the range of $3.6 billion to $3.7 billion. The new factory ramp cost of goods sold will range from $8 million to $10 million. And the factory start up expenses will range from $35 million to $40 million. Stock-based compensation is expected to be $115 million to $125 million, with approximately 20% allocated to the cost of goods sold. GAAP operating income is expected in the range of $900 million to $960 million which is slightly below our prior guidance at the high end of the range. Our revised effective tax rate will be 13% to 15% as more profit is recognized in higher tax locations. The 2% increase from prior guidance reduces EPS by about $0.20. Year-end 2011 fully diluted share count is expected to be 87 million to 88 million shares. Earnings per fully diluted share is expected to range from $9 to $9.50, $0.25 lower than prior guidance as we reflect the higher tax rate and a more aggressive pricing environment. We offset a portion of this by holding expenses flat. Capital expenditures for the year are expected to be $800 million to $900 million. Operating cash flow is projected in the range of $500 million to $600 million. Annual return on net assets will be 17% to 18%, in line with our goal to deliver returns exceeding our weighted average cost of capital by 5%.
Finally, Slide 21 is an updated of the expected quarterly profile of revenue and operating income dollars throughout 2011. Please note that as you read it horizontally from Q1 to Q4 on each chart, that sum of all quarters is 100%. Note that the third quarter, we are expecting to recognize less than 28% of our full year revenue and approximately 30% of our operating income guidance. The profile was driven by the following assumption.
First, Agua Caliente revenue recognition starts in the third quarter and accelerates into the fourth quarter. Second, Canadian projects under completed contract accounting showed revenue recognition primarily in the fourth quarter. Third, we have significant operating expense leverage in the second half. There's both and expenses but we'll continue to focus on R&D and market development. Additionally, start up expenses declined to about $8 million per quarter for Mesa and Vietnam. Finally, we will continue to use our systems pipeline as a buffer against European demand fluctuations. With this, we conclude our prepared remarks and open up the call for questions. Operator?

componenttext: Well, yes, I think originally we said between 4 and 6 when we ended the year and so what we're trying to do, force is to meet our customer expectations and manage the business with the fluctuation from the external markets. So for us, we feel that 450 megawatts are appropriate and deliver on commitments and get this balance between 2011 and '12 and the additional markets that exist. So we feel pretty good about that and we have enough demand in other locations to shift products. So the quarter was difficult in Q2, but we feel like 450 is the right number. And as Mark says, as we move forward to the end of the year, it just becomes 1 of the factors to how much you can put on the ground in total.

componenttext: Yes. The gigawatt, we mentioned, we plan to build in our objective public systems in 2012. So that number is correct. I think we feel good about the growth and expansion, and especially the support of India in terms of, we started out 10 megawatts in '10, and now, 200 megawatts this year and kind of signed up for the 250 between now and into 2012. So that's pretty exciting, I think. I think we'll see some stability in the markets as I mentioned in Germany as they've kind of stabilized somewhat and we hope to see some policy direction I guess some clarity the future of France, though, I think in Europe, were still kind of all bouncing back from the changes that took place in the first half and the challenges over there. So with we're not obviously talking about 2012, but getting the large pipeline applications funded, and into production is definitely something we're excited about and we'll be doing a lot of that between now and the end of the year.

componenttext: Well, I think what it does is, and the reason that we mentioned it is, we're proud of the success and the fact that is on manufacturing tooling. So we don't, as you know, we don't talk about these things unless we feel that we are well-positioned to be able to apply them. And the significance of it is, is that in our manufacturing environment, that we even beat the record that stood since 2001, which is more the experimental side. So what it means for our roadmap, is we're committed to delivering on the roadmap as we planned and still have that same target range in 2014 to get to that $0.52 to $0.63 range. So but obviously, we are stretching and doing what we can. I think I mentioned during the pitch that we're going to continue to achieve what we can do to accelerate that roadmap further and when we do roll out, we'll let you know.

componenttext: Yes, so the expenses within the quarter did include severance items which were slightly below I think what we indicated on the call. Last time, we thought it could be in the range of $6 million or so and below that. headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions on cost per watt. First of all, I believe certainly like comparing apples and oranges when you look at the Chinese, how they report cost per watt and how your report cost per watt and I'm wondering, if you can give us cost per watt, calc
componenttext: I had 2 questions on cost per watt. First of all, I believe certainly like comparing apples and oranges when you look at the Chinese, how they report cost per watt and how your report cost per watt and I'm wondering, if you can give us cost per watt, calculated the same way that the Chinese do, i.e. stripping out freight and overhead costs. And then secondly, I'm wondering if you look at cost per watt year-over-year, it hasn't really gone down even if you strip out stock-based comp about the ramp costs. It's down basically $0.01 even though, the efficiency is up like 50 bps and so I'm wondering why that is and why that's going to change going forward?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, we usually don't talk about it, but from what I know, in our analysis what the competitors do is to exclude things like shipping, warranty recycling, obviously. SBC, testing ramp, insurance another production costs and things like that. So ball
componenttext: Well, yes, we usually don't talk about it, but from what I know, in our analysis what the competitors do is to exclude things like shipping, warranty recycling, obviously. SBC, testing ramp, insurance another production costs and things like that. So ballpark on a comparative basis if you look at our cost per watt on the same basis it's about $0.68 in that range would be the equivalent comparison. And one of the things that I don't know maybe didn't come out during the presentation as well is, that we this year have changed somewhat how implement some of the changes with manufacturing team and we made the decision based on megawatts produced on a full year basis on line to take lines down for more extended periods. So say a week at a time whereas before would've done it piece to keep the lines up and running. And the reason we did that was twofold. So one is, the market conditions and the challenges in volume created an opportunity for it. And 2, we feel like for the total year, off of the same lines, we'll able to produce more megawatts. So it's kind of back to where we were I think last year, about this time where we talked about with all these lines we have and the Copy Smart approach, how do we change and make the changes appropriately and continue to bring the cost down? So we have a more of a stair step type of approach versus the incremental change quarter-over-quarter and that's really what we've been working on a part of what you're seeing. So it's still down year-over-year, but it's something that it takes more significant effort with all the lines that we have and some of the changes that we're making these we'll see the benefits of the change and effort we've made in Q4 of this year, both in the inefficiencies and line run rate. So a little bit lumpier than our past.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think we don't really talk about the individual incremental changes that we make and I think that the team is we have what we call the plan internally. so We have a commitment we have to use our shareholders and externally to roadmap that we
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think we don't really talk about the individual incremental changes that we make and I think that the team is we have what we call the plan internally. so We have a commitment we have to use our shareholders and externally to roadmap that we put in place $0.52 to $0.63 and the 8% to 10% improvement year-over-year and that's kind of how we got there. We mentioned today the improvement we're looking at things more installed cost per watt basis. So we made 30% improvement in the BoS cost and if we make the 20% improvement or 19%, we talked about between now and then, we will we should be able to exceed the $0.91 to $0.98 range that we talked about in 2009. So we made great progress there and that really is straight up between some inflation on raw materials, but then the great work could be ABC team and continued to drive the cost down. And then anything that we do, for Senegal force engineering with David and his team contributes to further BoS cost reductions. So at the 13.5% and 14.5% range, we have internal plans to accelerated as quickly as we can and hopefully you'll start to see that in our numbers and that's why we adopt a little bit of a different approach as to how we upgrade the lines and make changes.

componenttext: Obviously, this year, the working capital adjustments have been pretty based on the way Agua financing came through and how that deal was structured. I was just curious if you could talk a little bit about what we know now for 2011, whether that the cash inflow will be a little bit more evenly distributed and some of the factors there?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, to your question in clarity of the first half of the year, we have significant cash outflows associated with ramping some of those lower projects like Agua and we'll start to see the cash inflows start to flow in this year and then in Q3 and
componenttext: Yes, I think, to your question in clarity of the first half of the year, we have significant cash outflows associated with ramping some of those lower projects like Agua and we'll start to see the cash inflows start to flow in this year and then in Q3 and Q4, which will drive a significant operating cash flows for the second half of the year. And then we would expect the more balanced performance into 2012 especially once the annuity stream starts to flow and the gates open up on the progress payments, largely our matching your inflows and your outflows pretty well so we would expect 2012 to be dramatically different than what we see here for the first half of 2011.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Further to my colleague Steve's question, you may have seen the national feed-in tarriffs announced for China just a couple of weeks ago. I'm wondering as the sort of utility-scale levels, what your thoughts are there and whether that could impact the APA
componenttext: Further to my colleague Steve's question, you may have seen the national feed-in tarriffs announced for China just a couple of weeks ago. I'm wondering as the sort of utility-scale levels, what your thoughts are there and whether that could impact the APAC demand talking about.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we see this a firstly, a very positive step. It's one that we've been taking a look for sort of 1.15, 1.215 RMB per kilowatthour which is 16.75 yuan per better scenario we've seen before. What we need to be able to determine now with the officials th
componenttext: Yes, we see this a firstly, a very positive step. It's one that we've been taking a look for sort of 1.15, 1.215 RMB per kilowatthour which is 16.75 yuan per better scenario we've seen before. What we need to be able to determine now with the officials there is how to get through the process to ensure that certain projects are included in that feed-in tariff. So that, right now, what we are sorting through, but we see it as positive and I think that you should start to see more volume in China and especially that I mentioned mention of increasing the targets for 2015 and mention of the range from 20 to 50 gigawatts by 2020. So they're obviously huge goals in the process and we've been waiting for the clarity on something that make sense from a sustainable standpoint. And this tariff seems to and now you've got to get through the process of an approval to make sure that your project gets in the pipeline. So that's what we are working on.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, I mean it comes in 3 ways for us, essentially on the BoS, so there's an element of design, so how do we engineered materials and utilize the expertise of our guys from the experience that we've had in building plans to figure out smarter way to
componenttext: Okay. Yes, I mean it comes in 3 ways for us, essentially on the BoS, so there's an element of design, so how do we engineered materials and utilize the expertise of our guys from the experience that we've had in building plans to figure out smarter way to do it. There's a design element. There is the sourcing element that you mentioned. And then there is the productivity element, the speed with which we get the generation and that's a big part of the economics and the equation. So that's really the 3 ways. And I think last quarter, we talked a little bit about some inflation pressures which all I get to do is look at the commodities out there whether it's your copper and all of the things, we get pressure there, but we work through it from the other 2 means our design and productivity in terms of how we get things installed. So I think as we get smarter and we continue to improve efficiency in our own cost per watt, plus the focus on BoS that we can drive the installed cost per watt down and get us and close to the parity levels that we are targeting in 2014.

componenttext: Yes. I think we've done some initial work and some tenders in place. I would say the demand in total is something that's still evolving in those regions. There's a lot of interest, there are no formal policies in place to drive a lot of growth, yet, but we're positive the in southern Africa, northern Africa and in part South America will be a good market place, but it will take some time to develop it's what I would say. So probably ending 2012 beyond starting to see the real.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll take the pricing side of the question. We don't talk specifically about ASP  because we try to manage our customers and position in the market by providing and driving sellthroughs. So we want our customers to develop captive projects in the pip
componenttext: Yes. I'll take the pricing side of the question. We don't talk specifically about ASP  because we try to manage our customers and position in the market by providing and driving sellthroughs. So we want our customers to develop captive projects in the pipeline so we need to have some visibility about a year or so to do that. So what happened in Q2 and really in the first half is, that a lot of excess inventory in the system with the demand kind of stalling because of all the things we talked about earlier in the presentation. And when that happens, it puts a lot of pressure on the price aside and we work for rebate system with our customers to fund them and support them so the price pressure in external market is high from a third-party sales standpoint and that's part of what impacted our Q2 results. So we continue to manage and monitor that. We still feel confident in the concept and our approach to being able to buffer some of those fluctuations with our captive pipeline. And as we get near and nearer having those things finalized and funded especially here in the second half, as you said, Agua will start to recognize revenue on in Q3. That will become something is very vital for us to do, is to balance those 2 things together. So we want to be competitive in the third party market and we want to work with our customers to ensure they develop markets around the world.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for First Solar's Second Quarter 2001 (sic)  Conference Call. Today after the market closed, the company issued a press release announcing our second quarter financial results and our guidance update
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for First Solar's Second Quarter 2001 (sic)  Conference Call. Today after the market closed, the company issued a press release announcing our second quarter financial results and our guidance update for 2011. If you did not receive a copy of the press release, you can obtain one from the Investors section of First Solar's website at firstsolar.com. In addition, we have posted a presentation for this call, as well as well as key quarterly statistics and historical data on financial and operating performance on our IR website. We will be discussing the presentation during this call and webcast. An audio replay of the conference call will also be available approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of the call. The audio replay will remain available until August 9 at 7:30 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time and can be accessed by dialing (888) 203-1112 if you're calling from within the United States, or (719) 457-0820 if you're calling from outside the United States, and entering the replay pass code 6647385. A replay of the webcast will be available on the Investors section of firstsolar.com approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of the call, and will remain available for 90 calendar days. If you're a subscriber of FactSet or Thomson One, you can obtain a written transcript. 
With me today are Rob Gillette, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Widmar, Chief Financial Officer. Rob will present an overview of the company's second quarter results and give you an update of the market and business. Mark will review our second quarter financial results and update guidance for 2011. We will then open up the call for questions. [Operator Instructions] First Solar has allocated approximately one hour for today's call. I want to remind everyone that all financial numbers reported and discussed on today's call are based on Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, except free cash flow, which is a non-GAAP measure, which is reconciled to operating cash flow in the back of our presentation. 
Now I'd like to make a brief statement regarding our forward-looking remarks that you may hear on today's call. During the course of this call, the company will make projections and other comments that are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Securities laws. The forward-looking statements in this call are based on current information and expectations, are subject to uncertainties and changes in circumstances, and do not constitute guarantees of future performance. Those statements involve a number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements, including the risks as described in the company's most recent annual report on Form 10-K and other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. First Solar assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking information contained in this call or with respect to the announcements described herein. 
During the third quarter, First Solar will be attending the following conferences and events: first, Pacific Crest Tech Conference in Vail, Colorado on August 8; Bank of America Merrill Lynch Clean Tech Conference in New York City, September 13; DnB NOR Renewable Energy Conference in Oslo on September 13; ThinkEquity's Growth Conference in New York City on September 14; Ardour's Capital Tech Conference in New York City, September 15; Credit Suisse Future of Energy Conference in New York City, September 27. And now it's my pleasure to introduce Rob Gillette, Chief Executive Officer of First Solar. Rob?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Larry. Welcome to our Q2 earnings call. As all of you know, it was a challenging quarter for the solar PV industry, including First Solar, but our business model and our execution served us well and we're positioned for a significant and be
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Larry. Welcome to our Q2 earnings call. As all of you know, it was a challenging quarter for the solar PV industry, including First Solar, but our business model and our execution served us well and we're positioned for a significant and better second half.
Starting with Slide 6. Q2 net sales of $533 million, that is about 6% lower than last quarter, primarily due to lower average selling prices. Solar PV's policy incentives in Italy, Germany and France adversely impacted demand in the second quarter. Net sales are also impacted as we reallocated modules to the systems business which we did not recognize as revenue within the quarter.
Second quarter net income was $61 million or 11.5% of net sales, resulting in diluted EPS of $0.70. Return on net assets was 13.1% on a 4-quarter rolling basis representing an EVA of about 1.1%. Our cash and marketable securities balance of $515 million declined $198 million sequentially as we invested CapEx for new factories and continued construction in several systems projects.
In addition, shipments were weighted to the end of the quarter as customers delayed orders until the European policy changes were better understood.
Despite the challenging European market in the first half of the year, our 2011 outlook remains solid due to our differentiated and resilient business model. We expect significantly better performance in the remainder of 2011 as we build projects from our systems pipeline, develop promising new markets and execute our cost and efficiency roadmaps. As a result, our updated 2011 EPS guidance is $9 to $9.50 for fully diluted share which includes 450 megawatts of system sales and some updated assumptions which Mark will discuss later. Significant drivers in the change is the 2% increase in the effective tax rate or about $0.20 per share reduction, driven by the increased portion of profits in the U.S.
Moving on now to operations. Q2 production was 483 megawatts, up 40% versus the prior year and up 19% quarter-over-quarter. This sequential increase is driven by the production ramp of the KLM 6 factory and early start up of Frankfurt-Oder 2. Module revenue shipments were up 6% quarter-over-quarter, which partially offset the decline in average selling prices. A portion of its incremental production also went to systems project construction for which revenue has not yet been recognized. Our conversion efficiency was 11.7%, which is up 0.5 percentage points year-over-year and flat quarter-over-quarter. Module manufacturing and cost per watt was $0.75, which is flat quarter-over-quarter. The benefit of our modules from low-cost manufacturing sites was offset by FX, lower line throughput, higher spending and factory ramp costs. Core cost which excluded the ramp penalty and stock-based compensation, were $0.73 per watt. And we're very pleased to announce that our Malaysian plant have achieved a new core cost milestone of $0.69 per watt.
Annual capacity per line decreased by 2 megawatts quarter-over-quarter to 62.1-megawatt per line. Line throughput and cost per watt were both impacted this quarter as we decided to take advantage of softer industry demand, scheduled downtime and begin to implement conversion efficiency improvements which we expect will have a meaningful impact by the end of the year.
We also reached a milestone with our standard utility-scale Balance of Systems by achieving a cost level of $0.99 per watt. BoS is down 29% from the second quarter of 2009. We are now also close to our 2014 target for standard BoS of $0.91 to $0.98 per watt and can improve further as our planned module efficiencies increase from 13.5% to 14.5% by the end of 2014. This major accomplishment is the result of our experience in positioning, investment in engineering and R&D, and cycles of learning from almost 400 megawatts of DC of projects built to-date.
To summarize our manufacturing capacity addition, Malaysia 5 and 6 are at full production; Frankfurt-Oder 2 began ramping a month early and is expected to be at full production by the end of the third quarter. Construction of our Mesa, Arizona and Vietnam sites are progressing on schedule for shipments in the third quarter of 2012.
Moving now to Page 7. Despite the recent market turbulence, our growth strategy remains unchanged. We are focused on our mission of making solar affordable and sustainable to gain access to the multi-terawatt peak electricity generation market. We are currently in the transition phase as FiTs and other government policies are progressing towards a parity and market diversification continues. First Solar has made significant progress reducing a levelized cost of electricity, diversifying geographically, and we expect price declines to continue to drive demand elasticity.
On the next page, you can see we've made significant progress in lowering our total systems cuts by 30% in 3 years. We can reduce that by another 19%, we believe that we can provide turnkey utility-scale systems that generate power at an LCOE of $0.10 to $0.12 per kilowatt hour in high radiant zones like the U.S. Southwest, India, China, Australia, the Middle East, Spain and Italy. This is what will drive our participation in the peak electricity generation market.
Now turning to Page 9. Our Module manufacturing cost, as you noticed, steadily declined since 2008 and future improvements to our year-end 2014 target are primarily driven by conversion efficiency growth, 13.5% to 14.5% efficiency and annual line throughput improvements to 80-megawatt per line. We are committed to our long-term Module conversion efficiency roadmap and we invest heavily in technology to achieve this end. Our investments in technology are not focused on hero cells. We emphasize practical improvements with the low-cost pathways to implementation and production. However, it is nice to see that when we integrate several of these improvements, we are able to deliver a device that does exceed the prior world record. We recently received a confirmation from NREL that First Solar's cells achieved a record 17.3% efficiency for CdTe thin-film cell which breaks the previous record of 16.7% which was set in 2001.
Unlike other cell records, this cell was constructed using only full-scale manufacturing processes and commercial materials. Therefore, we believe they can be reproduced economically. This is an important milestone because it validates our technology capabilities and significantly improves CdTe thin-film efficiencies and it provides confidence in the improvements we have planned over the next few years. Our achievement is a direct result of our industry-leading annual investment in research and development, and the efforts of the committed team that you see here. We are considering approaches to accelerate Module efficiency quicker than our curent roadmap of the 13.5% to 14.5% by the end of 2014 to support rooftop and other high-efficiency applications.
The next page shows how we have been steadily diversifying geographically and investing in market development. Our North American business has grown from 17% to 25% of megawatt shift and is expected to be our number 1 market in 2012. In India, supportive policies and new local partners are driving strong growth and we expect India to account for more than 10% of our megawatts this year. Our North American pipeline and new markets like India are helping to offset European market uncertainties and both are expected to be multi-gigawatt sustainable markets. In the second quarter, North America and India combined, represented almost 50% of our revenues.
Moving to Page 11. The market development we're focused on executing on North American systems pipeline, managing through European market uncertainty and developing new markets. In North America, we made progress executing on the 450-megawatt DC of plant 2011 systems build and have flexibility to build up to 500 megawatts. Agua Caliente now has a significant portion of the BoS completed and we have begun installing modules. The sale of Agua Caliente to NRG and the closing of the debt financing including the DOE loan guarantee are expected soon. All major steps have been completed and we are in the funding stage. We will begin to recognize the revenue for the construction of this 290-megawatt AC system in Q3. When completed, it will be more than 3x larger than any PV power plant currently operating.
We are focused on adding to our systems pipeline on a global basis through new RFPs, EPC agreements and acquisitions. For example, we recently added 150-megawatt AC, EPC agreement with Sempra Generation for Copper Mountain 2 in Boulder City, Nevada. This growth to our systems pipelines is about 2.6 gigawatts. Sunlight, Topaz and AVSR1 achieved $4.5 billion of DOE loans, conditional commitments in Q2. Topaz received its conditional use permit and is in the legal appeal period. AVSR is expected to begin construction in the third quarter. In Europe, we are managing through market uncertainty due to feed-in tariff and policy changes. The delayed implementation of a new decree in Italy, the slow start to Germany after January FiT reductions and lack of clarity with respect to France's tender process contributed to excess channel inventories for the industry.
During the second quarter, we worked with customers to enable discrete project realization and we increased rebates to enable distributors to sell-through. In France, First Solar and our partners are realizing 250 megawatts of projects in 2011. Now we have a clearer picture in Italy, Germany, France and the U.K., but the new policies have created a more challenging operating environment.
We are making progress in developing new markets. Our 2011 plant shipments in India have now grown to more than 200 megawatts, which is up from 100 megawatts in Q1 and 10 megawatts sold in 2010. We recently signed 4 new Module customers in India and have contracted more than 250 megawatts year-to-date for deliveries in 2011 and into 2012. We are seeing an increasing number of tenders as well in the Middle East for 2012 and beyond.
On Page 12, this is the latest analyst consensus forecast of global PV market demand. On average, the 15 analysts included in this survey estimate that the 2011 market will grow to 19.8 gigawatts, up 19% year-over-year, primarily driven by North America, Italy, India and China. The analysts estimates estimate a compound growth rate of 12% from 2010  to 2013 as the markets diversified in North America, India, China, Japan, the Middle East and the rest of the world beyond Europe. Government policies, lower pricing, stellar resource and economics are driving market diversification and demand elasticity. These markets are transitioned into sustainable markets as we anticipated in our growth strategy.
In general, we believe demand in the major solar markets will improve in the second half of 2011 after a difficult first half. We see significant growth opportunities long-term as new markets are emerging and we advance towards group parity. The German market is recovering from a slow start and appears to be ramping towards around 4 to 5 gigawatt in 2011. The recent EEG decision provides good long-term visibility and we our well positioned as at the German manufacturer.
In Italy, the market is adjusting to the new CE4 [ph] published in May and is recovering from the policy interruption in the first half. Demand is improving and is expected to be 2 to 3 gigawatts in 2011. Stable and reliable regular utility frameworks will be the key elements for long-term sustainable development of the Italian market. First Solar technology and Europe manufacturing expansion will help to position us for success in the Italian market.
France's policy does not provide sufficient long-term visibility at the moment while we continue to be optimistic about the longer-term opportunity. In the short-term, due to building grandfather projects, the French market should range from 500 to 800 megawatts. Our 2-line facility planned for Blanquefort remains on indefinite hold.
The North American market should double to more than 2 gigawatts this year. In California, over 1 gigawatt of RFOs were issued for the 2011 cycle to comply with the 33% RPS requirement. Overtime, the requirement for government subsidies may decline as ROEs or early adopters do the same.
In China, the government is in the process of developing a longer-term plan for the market. With the potential to increase their 2020 goal from 20 to 50 gigawatts. China recently announced the new national FiT with the potential to provide sustainable economics at 1.15 RMB per kilowatt hour. We continue to see strong momentum in India, the market is expected to grow to about 500 megawatts in 2011.
In Australia, we were unfortunately, not selected for the first phase of the Solar Flagship's program but remained well-positioned for the second phase. Solar growth will be strongly supported in the future by the recently announced national carbon legislation, which has committed to invest $10 billion in non-wind large scale renewables and to the implementation of state solar programs targeting utility-scale projects.
In Southeast Asia, we see encouraging signs of early-stage development in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines. Finally, we see great potential in the Middle East. There are challenges facing oil-exporting countries with the rapid growth in domestic energy needs, tam tenders for utility-scale projects are underway and we expect to see more robust renewable policies that could drive a several-hundred-megawatt market in just a few years.
On the next page, you can see how we've grown our systems pipeline over time. We signed a 150-megawatt AC EPC agreement with Sempra Generation for the expansion of Copper Mountain in Boulder City, Nevada. This site was originally developed by First Solar and sold to Sempra, which has signed a PPA with PG&E for the electricity generated at Copper Mountain 2. Our goal is to continue to replace current year construction with new PPA or EPC agreements to continue to grow our pipeline.
The orange line shows our increasing project construction from 12 megawatts in 2008, to the planned 450 megawatts in 2011, and we expect to build 1 gigawatt in 2012. The slide also illustrates the expansion and diversification of our Utility Systems customer base, including IPPs, utilities, and financial investors. In the back of this presentation, Slide 23, shows the details of the North American contracted projects we are executing and have under development.
On Page 14, you can see some of the project activity in the second quarter. We now have completed a significant portion of the mounting instructions on Agua Caliente and have begun module installation. The Amherstburg 2 and Santa Teresa projects are nearly completed, and Paloma and PNM projects are ahead of schedule.
To summarize, we continued to execute in the quarter despite a challenging European market and remained focused on achieving our mission. Our visibility is improving for the second half of the year, an increasing portion of our revenues and profits are under our control as we construct our systems pipeline and continue to diversify geographically. Our LCOE is approaching grid parity which should drive elasticity and demand and a growth of sustainable markets. We are investing for growth in the United States, India, the Middle East, Australia and China. We are executing a systems pipeline and we're adding to it. We continue to expand our factories and drive our products roadmaps. We achieved a major BoS in module efficiency milestone as a result of our investment in R&D and our continuous improvement processes, and we have the financial strength to continue investing in the long-term future of our business.
Finally, our 2011 guidance is solid due to our differentiated and resilient business model. Now I'd like to turn it over to Mark who will discuss our second quarter financial performance and updated guidance for 2011. Mark?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob, and good afternoon. Looking at Slide 17, our net sales for the second quarter were $533 million, down 6% quarter-over-quarter. The decrease was primarily driven by lower ASPs which were down 13% quarter-over-quarter as we reduce prices to
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob, and good afternoon. Looking at Slide 17, our net sales for the second quarter were $533 million, down 6% quarter-over-quarter. The decrease was primarily driven by lower ASPs which were down 13% quarter-over-quarter as we reduce prices to sell-through such is our geographic mix. As Rob said earlier, the quarter started slowly due to the European policy uncertainties which adversely impacted demand for the quarter. These impacts were partially offset by the positive effects of increased systems revenue recognition driven by Santa Teresa, Paloma and PNM. Our EPC revenue mix increased from 8% of total net sales from the first quarter to 11% of net sales in the second quarter. We also increased the module allocation for the systems business during the quarter and to make contract auxiliary schedules which will result in revenue recognition of the second half of the year.
The early increase from Q2 to Q1, however, the stronger euro had a minor negative impact on net sales as we were significant hedged in line with our long-term strategy. Gross margin was 36.6%, down 9.2 percentage points from the prior quarter. The decline was the result of the ASPs decreases, a mix shift both geographically and to more system sales and an unfavorable FX impact. Module gross margin was 40.2%, down 9.5 percentage points from the prior quarter. Operating expenses were flat quarter-over-quarter. Slightly higher R&D expenses associated with efficiency improvements were offset by lower production start up costs as Frankfurt-Oder and Malaysia ramped. SG&A was flat quarter-over-quarter. We focused on managing our expense growth to help partially offset lower gross margin.
Operating income was $65 million compared to $129 million in the first quarter. The decline was due to the decrease in total net sales and gross margins. Operating margin for the quarter was 12.1% compared to 22.8% in the prior quarter. As we progress through the year, our operating margin is levered to the timing of the systems revenue recognition. Second quarter net income was $61 million or $0.70 per fully diluted share. The effective tax rate grows 2.2 percentage points to 15% due to the mixed shift of profits to higher tax jurisdictions which lowered EPS by $0.02 in the quarter.
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow summary. Cash and marketable securities were down quarter-over-quarter with $515 million. Accounts receivable trade balance rose quarter-over-quarter due to the nominal shipments as policy changes in Europe pushed our customers orders to the back half of the quarter. Accounts receivable non-build increased because of growth in North America business and the timing of project billing cycle as specified in customer contracts. Inventories increased as we increase production from a KLM 6 and FFO2 and due to more module and balance systems materials in transit for EPC installations in the third quarter. Project assets rose as we continue to develop North America project sites. We continue to invest to increase our factory capacity and we have the long-term bits to help finance Malaysia and German expansions.
Operating cash flow was negative $203 million and free cash flow was negative $408 million. We spent $221 million for capital expenditures and depreciation was $54 million. Cash flow was impacted by accounts receivable linearity, growth in project assets and inventory and deferred revenue growth on more construction in progress in our systems business. Also, we invested about $52 million more on capital expenditures when compared to the first quarter of 2011.
As expected, we consumed cash in the first half of the year and planned to generate cash in the second half of 2011 as we complete the sales projects in our systems business. Our balance sheet remains strong with a debt-to-equity ratio of 10%. This brings me to our updated guidance for 2011. We have made several key assumptions underlying our guidance. Our stock exchange rate assumption is $1.40 per euro. For the third quarter, about 69% of our net sales and all of our expected net income are hedged in an average rate of $1.34 per euro. For the balance of the year, about 72% of our net sales and all of our expected net income are hedged in an average rate of $1.35 per euro. As of today, a $0.01 change in the euro-dollar slot exchange rate would impact our revenue guidance for the year by about $1 million and will not change our net income guidance since we are fully hedged for 2011. Our Module pricing reflects European FiT changes in 2011 it is embedded to enable sell-through economics and is based on our estimate of the current competitive market.
We plan to build approximately 450-megawatt DC of system projects in North America. We have the flexibility to increase this amount to 500 megawatts should the demand in other markets fall short of our current expectations. However, that flexibility has declined and will continue to decline as we progress through the year.
We plan to minimize our expense growth in the second half of 2011. Malaysia Plants 5 and 6 are fully ramped and we are ramping FFO2 in Q3. Our capital expenditures is primarily for capacity expansion in Vietnam and the U.S..
Page 20 shows that based on these assumptions, we expect net sales to be in the range of $3.6 billion to $3.7 billion. The new factory ramp 
penalty and profitable sale will range from $8 million to $10 million. And the factory start-up expenses will range from $35 million to $40 million. Stock-based compensation is expected to be $115 million to $125 million, with approximately 20% allocated to the cost of goods sold. GAAP operating income is expected in the range of $900 million to $960 million which is slightly below our prior guidance at the high end of the range. Our revised effective tax rate will be 13% to 15% as more profit is recognized in higher tax locations. The 2% increase from prior guidance reduces EPS by about $0.20. Year-end 2011 fully diluted share count is expected to be 87 million to 88 million shares. Earnings per fully diluted share is expected to range from $9 to $9.50, $0.25 lower than prior guidance as we reflect a higher tax rate and a more aggressive pricing environment. We offset a portion of this by holding expenses flat. Capital expenditures for the year are expected to be $800 million to $900 million. Operating cash flow is projected in the range of $500 million to $600 million. Annual return on net assets will be 17% to 18%, in line with our goal to deliver returns exceeding our weighted average cost of capital by 5%.
Finally, Slide 21 is an update of the expected quarterly profile of revenue and operating income dollars throughout 2011. Please note that as you read across horizontally from Q1 to Q4 on each chart, the sum of all quarters is 100%. Note that at third quarter, we are expecting to recognize less than 28% of our full year revenue and approximately 30% of our operating income guidance. The profile was driven by the following assumption: first, Agua Caliente revenue recognition starts in the third quarter and accelerates into the fourth quarter; second, Canadian projects under completed contract accounting show revenue recognition primarily in the fourth quarter; third, we have significant operating expense leverage in the second half. We are slow in the growth rate in expenses but we'll continue to focus on R&D and market development. Additionally, start-up expenses declined to about $8 million per quarter for Mesa and Vietnam. Finally, we will continue to use our systems pipeline as a buffer against European demand fluctuations. With this, we conclude our prepared remarks and open up the call for questions. Operator?

componenttext: It looks like you're upside flexIbility to the North American region is now only about 50 megawatts, not the 150 megawatts. Is there a reason why you chose not to upsize North America more and does this help with the 2012 visibility and the 2012 profit margin?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I think originally we said between 4 and 6 when we entered the year and so what we're trying to do, of course, is to meet our customer expectations and manage the business with the fluctuation from the external markets. So for us, we feel that
componenttext: Well, yes, I think originally we said between 4 and 6 when we entered the year and so what we're trying to do, of course, is to meet our customer expectations and manage the business with the fluctuation from the external markets. So for us, we feel that 450 megawatts are appropriate and deliver on commitments and gives us balance between 2011 and '12 in the external markets that exists. So we feel pretty good about that and we have enough demand in other locations to shift products. So the quarter was difficult in Q2, but we feel like 450 is the right number. And as Mark says, as we move forward to the end of the year, it just becomes a limiting factor as to how much you can put on the ground in total.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: How many crystalline silicon companies over the years about higher efficiency cells and plan for high-efficiency modules, why are or how are your new high-efficiency cells more credible that they'll return into panels and then how are you thinking about t
componenttext: How many crystalline silicon companies over the years about higher efficiency cells and plan for high-efficiency modules, why are or how are your new high-efficiency cells more credible that they'll return into panels and then how are you thinking about the strategy and timing of rolling that out?

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say this, they are more credible because firstly, they're actually done on manufacturing tooling price. So it's not something that's done in the lab. As well, we also don't talk about a number of different things as I said, we don't do our R&
componenttext: Yes. I would say this, they are more credible because firstly, they're actually done on manufacturing tooling price. So it's not something that's done in the lab. As well, we also don't talk about a number of different things as I said, we don't do our R&D work specifically targeting hero cells because hero cells are not what we can replicate in our facilities. So we don't -- we've had a history of and we maintained a history of only talking about things that we think we can implement in our manufacturing process. So I think in general, we're very confident and made confident by the efforts of the team and the people that you saw there when you talked about during the FiTs. So we've got a lot of record sales and as you know, efficiencies and the numbers we use are 11 to 7 that I've stated is an average of all sort of production lines. So even on our manufacturing lines today, there is prices where we make higher efficiencies and we make sure to report the average.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wonder, if you could at least qualitatively discuss your visibility into 2012, both in the U.S. where I think you've said that you're now looking at doing a gigawatt of systems business, plus you have the DOE sweeteners, I guess, it's always come throug
componenttext: I wonder, if you could at least qualitatively discuss your visibility into 2012, both in the U.S. where I think you've said that you're now looking at doing a gigawatt of systems business, plus you have the DOE sweeteners, I guess, it's always come through. And then also, outside the U.S. where nobody really knows what's going to happen, but if you have any thoughts about what next year might look like outside the U.S., just kind of curious if you could talk qualitatively about your visibility into next year.

headline: First Solar, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. The gigawatt, we mentioned, we plan to build in our objective pipeline systems in 2012. So that number is correct. I think we feel good about the growth and expansion, and especially the support of India in terms of -- we started out with the 10 mega
componenttext: Yes. The gigawatt, we mentioned, we plan to build in our objective pipeline systems in 2012. So that number is correct. I think we feel good about the growth and expansion, and especially the support of India in terms of -- we started out with the 10 megawatts in '10, and now, 200 megawatts this year and they kind of signed up for 250 between now and into 2012. So that's pretty exciting, I think. I think we'll see some stability in the markets as I mentioned in Germany as they've kind of stabilized somewhat and we hope to see some policy direction that gives us some clarity on the future of France. So I think in Europe, were still kind of all bouncing back from the changes that took place in the first half and the challenges over there. So we don't -- we're not obviously talking about 2012, but getting the large pipeline applications funded, and into production is definitely something we're excited about and we'll be doing a lot of that between now and the end of the year.

componenttext: Yes, I think, yes, approximately revenue-wise and mix you'd have to look at where we were doing EPC revenues around. So you can't  -- it's not a straight map in that way. But in general, we've -- that's why we mentioned revenue but it's quite different. I think for the balance of the year, we feel like we've worked with our customers to provide pricing and support to drive sell-through, and then we plan, as you know, to start executing on these major projects in Q3 and Q4. So I think as we said, 2011, second half will be much better than the first.
